questions.text: A person had a meal at 8 pm and records blood glucose at 7 am on the next day which was 180mg/dl. What’s the source of glucose in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hepatic Glycogenolysis The person is fasting for last 11 hours. First source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose that can provide glucose for upto 2 hours after meals (option a is excluded). After that liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose for next 12-18 hours of fasting (option c is answer). Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glycogen is exhausted i.e. only after 12 hours onwards (option b is wrong answer). Muscle glycogen cannot maintain blood glucose as the end-product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6-phosphate due to absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle (option D is wrong answer). This enzyme is only present in liver cell’s ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose.

questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mismatch repair Mismatch Repair (MMR) defect leads to Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). Nucleotide excision Repair (NER) defect leads to Xeroderma Pigmentosa. Defect in base excision repair leads to MUTYH associated polyposis. Homologous Repair (HR) defect leads to Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome, Breast cancer, Ataxia-Telangiectasia like disorder.

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2:

options.label: A
options.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

options.label: B
options.text: E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

options.label: C
options.text: E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

options.label: D
options.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.correct_answer: A. E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase The picture depicts components and working of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex of link reaction. It requires vitamins B 1 , B 2 , B 3 , B 5 and lipoic acid as cofactors. Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles Component Name Cofactor Role E1 Pyruvate Dehydrogenase TPP (B 1 ) Decarboxylation of Pyruvate and transfer of remaining compound to Lipoic acid E2 Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase Lipoic acid, CoA (B 5 ) Transfer of acetyl group and acetyl CoA synthesis E3 Dihydrolipoyl Dehydrogenase NAD (B 3 ) and FAD (B 2 ) Transfer electrons to NAD and FAD

questions.text: A 35-year old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Niacin The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Pellagra is characterized by 3Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Death and delirium and depression can also occur. Pellagra can also be caused due to Isoniazid therapy as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra. Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively. Main symptoms of Riboflavin deficiency are Cheilosis, Glossitis and Corneal vascularization. Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin needs to be supplied in the diet of patients with Cystathionine beta synthase defect?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cysteine Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) is involved in the synthesis of cysteine from dietary methionine. Cysteine synthesis require methionine, serine and vitamin B6. The reactions are summarized in the diagram: So, in case of CBS deficiency there will be no formation of cystathionine and cysteine. so, cysteine becomes essential and needs to be taken in diet.

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dl) & LDL (220 mg/dl) were found to be raised. Statins were given to this patient. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Familial hypercholesterolemia All of the conditions i.e. tendon xanthomas, high serum cholesterol and LDL levels and statin therapy which is given to inhibit rate limiting enzyme HMG CoA reductase of cholesterol biosynthesis indicate that cholesterol is raised in this patient. So, the most probable diagnosis is Familial hypercholesterolemia aka Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia that occur due to deficiency of LDL receptor on liver or Apo B100 mutation . Lipoprotein lipase deficiency or Apo C- II defect cause familial hyperchylomicronemia or Type I hyperlipoproteinemia with raised plasma chylomicrons and TG levels. In Tangier’s disease, there is defect in ABCA1 receptors causing low levels of plasma HDL.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness, anemia, bony pain & hepatosplenomegaly. A histological picture is shown with cells in bone marrow. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gluco-Cerebrosidase The picture show macrophages with typical crumpled tissue paper appearance/ wrinkled appearance that is highly characteristic of Gaucher’s disease (most common lysosomal storage disease). Glucocerebrosides accumulate in reticuloendothelial system due to deficiency of enzyme β-Glucocerebrosidase. These patients have bony pain, pathological fractures, hepatosplenomegaly, but no mental retardation. Glucose 6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke’s disease (a Glycogen storage disorder) Hexosaminidase A and Beta-Galactosidase deficiency cause Tay Sach’s disease and Krabbe’s disease respectively.

questions.text: Transparency of corneal endothelium is maintained by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratan sulphate Cornea has mainly keratan Sulphate and maintains corneal transparency. Keratan sulfate-I is present in cornea while keratan sulfate-II is present in cartilages. Keratan sulphate do not contain any uronic acid. Cornea also has some Chondroitin Sulfate. Heparan sulfate is present on cell surfaces and is required for cell adhesion. Hyaluronic acid has a role in cell migration during morphogenesis and also in wound healing.

Solution:

Niacin This is Casal’s necklace shown in picture, which occurs in Vitamin B 3 / Niacin deficiency. Niacin can be formed in the body from amino acid tryptophan. Niacin deficiency can be caused by: Dietary deficiency of tryptophan Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency Carcinoid syndrome Hartnup’s disease

questions.text: A 25-year old patient presented with dark urine, which further blackens on exposure to air. What’s the enzyme defect in this case?
questions.correct_answer: B. Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase This is a case of alkaptonuria which is an inborn error in catabolism of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase or Di-Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase. The IUPAC name of homogentisate is 2,5-Dihydroxy Phenyl Acetate. The older name of this enzyme was Homogentisate oxidase. In alkaptonuria patients, fresh urine is normal in color, but on standing it turns black due to oxidation of excess homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine. For complete list of phenyalanine and tyrosine catabolism defects, refer to topic aromatic amino acids.

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATPs were produced. Later a compound was added, and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What’s that compound?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oligomycin Out of all the option given, only Oligomycin inhibits both oxidation and phosphorylation. 2,4 dinitrophenol is an uncoupler which only inhibits phosphorylation but not oxidation. Antimycin and rotenone are inhibitors of ETC complexes III and I respectively. They will also inhibit oxidation but will not inhibit phosphorylation directly. So, the best answer is Oligomycin.

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitot’s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phrynoderma The symptoms of patient clearly indicate vitamin A deficiency. One of the other clinical feature of vitamin A deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis aka Phrynoderma which is characterized by excessive keratinization of certain area of body such as elbows and knees. Vitamin A prevents hyperkeratinization.

questions.text: A 4-year old boy presented with developmental delay, recurrent chest infections and worsening bony pain. His serum PTH was normal. Calcium was normal and phosphate was low. There is no response to Vitamin D. The probable diagnosis is:

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D dependent rickets type I

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D dependent rickets type II

questions.explanation:
Solution:

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets As there is no response to Vitamin D supplementation so it cannot be option c and d. Vitamin D dependent rickets type I is due to 1-alpha hydroxylase defect in kidneys causing 25-OH D3 elevation whereas in Vitamin D dependent rickets type II there is a receptor defect leading to increased 1,25-dihydroxy D3 levels. In nutritional rickets, there is dietary deficiency of calcium, but calcium levels can be made normal due to 2 o increase in PTH. But in this case PTH levels are normal, so, nutritional rickets can also be ruled out. So, the only option left is X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets which is an X-linked inherited disorder characterized by urinary phosphate wasting. The PTH and Ca 2+ levels are normal, but phosphate levels are low in this case leading to soft and weak bones.

questions.text: A child is presented with multiple times loose stools. He is managed with ORS. Glucose in ORS is absorbed via which transporter in GIT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SGLT-1 Glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestinal lumen into intestinal cell via secondary active transport using sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT-1). On the other hand, the glucose from the intestine cell in to blood at basolateral membrane is transported via passive transporter GLUT-2 (see fig)
